name: Cause and Effect Analysis (Fishbone/Ishikawa)
description: Systematically identify and explore all possible causes of a specific problem. Visual framework for comprehensive root cause analysis when multiple factors contribute.

structure.name: Problem Statement
structure.description: Clearly define the specific problem to be analyzed (the 'effect')

structure.name: Category Identification
structure.description: Select major cause categories (typically: People, Process, Materials, Equipment, Environment, Management)

structure.name: Brainstorming Causes
structure.description: For each category, brainstorm all possible contributing factors

structure.name: Sub-Cause Analysis
structure.description: Drill down into each identified cause to find more specific sub-causes

structure.name: Relationship Mapping
structure.description: Identify relationships and interdependencies between different causes

structure.name: Prioritization
structure.description: Identify most likely root causes based on evidence and impact

structure.name: Solution Planning
structure.description: Develop targeted solutions for prioritized root causes

prompts: What specific problem are we trying to solve? Define it clearly.
What are the major categories of causes we should consider? (People, Process, Materials, etc.)
Within [category], what specific factors could contribute to this problem?
For each cause identified, what are the underlying sub-causes?
How do these different causes relate to and influence each other?
Which causes are most likely to be the root causes? What evidence supports this?
What solutions can address each prioritized root cause?
How can we verify that we've found the true root causes?
when_to_use: When complex problems have multiple potential causes
When team-based problem solving is needed
When quality issues require systematic investigation
When previous attempts to solve problems have failed
When analyzing process failures or systemic issues
When visual documentation of causes is helpful
when_not_to_use: For simple problems with obvious single causes
When quick decisions are needed and time is limited
When working alone without diverse perspectives
When problems are urgent and require immediate action

examples.title: Software Quality Issues
examples.description: Problem: High bug rate. Categories: People (skill gaps), Process (inadequate testing), Equipment (slow computers), Materials (poor requirements), Environment (tight deadlines). Identified root cause: Process - insufficient automated testing.

examples.title: Customer Service Complaints
examples.description: Problem: Long response times. Categories: People (training), Process (workflow), Materials (information systems), Environment (staffing levels). Found multiple contributing causes requiring coordinated solutions.

validation_status.validation_notes: Widely used quality management tool for systematic problem analysis
